summary.embedding_text: Fix duplicate and self-referencing RLS on organization_members that causes infinite recursion and ambiguous access. Replace overlapping policies with a single consolidated SELECT policy that uses a SECURITY DEFINER membership check to avoid self-recursion. Also remove conflicting allow-all on organizations.

symptoms: Infinite recursion in policy for relation "organization_members" during SELECT
Ambiguous/duplicated policies produce unexpected access paths
context.observed_error: Failed to fetch user organizations: infinite recursion detected in policy for relation "organization_members"

bad_policies.name: Users can view members of organizations they belong to
bad_policies.sql: CREATE POLICY "Users can view members of organizations they belong to" ON organization_members FOR SELECT USING (EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM organization_members om WHERE om.organization_id = organization_members.organization_id AND om.user_id = auth.uid()));
bad_policies.why_bad: Self-references organization_members inside its own policy ‚Üí recursive policy evaluation.

bad_policies.name: organization_members_own_only
bad_policies.sql: CREATE POLICY "organization_members_own_only" ON organization_members FOR SELECT USING (user_id = auth.uid());
bad_policies.why_bad: Duplicates the 'own memberships' intent; overlapping SELECT policies make behavior harder to reason about.

bad_policies.name: Service role can manage all memberships
bad_policies.sql: CREATE POLICY "Service role can manage all memberships" ON organization_members FOR ALL USING (auth.role() = 'service_role');
bad_policies.why_bad: Not inherently bad; keep as explicit server-side override.

related_issues.sql: CREATE POLICY "organizations_allow_all" ON organizations FOR ALL USING (true);
related_issues.why_bad: Overrides restrictive SELECT policy ('Users can view organizations they are members of'). Enables broad unintended access.

good_pattern.title: Consolidated, non-recursive RLS using SECURITY DEFINER helper
good_pattern.helper_fn_sql:
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION public.is_member_of(org_id uuid, uid uuid)
RETURNS boolean
LANGUAGE sql
SECURITY DEFINER
SET search_path = public
AS $$
  SELECT EXISTS (
    SELECT 1
    FROM public.organization_members m
    WHERE m.organization_id = org_id
      AND m.user_id = uid
  );
$$;
good_pattern.organizations_fix_sql:
DROP POLICY IF EXISTS "organizations_allow_all" ON public.organizations;
CREATE POLICY "orgs_read_members_only" ON public.organizations FOR SELECT USING (public.is_member_of(id, auth.uid()) OR auth.role() = 'service_role');
why_good: Avoids self-referencing the protected table inside its own policy.
One SELECT policy ‚Üí predictable behavior and easier audits.
SERVICE ROLE carve-out remains explicit.
Organizations visibility aligns with membership helper; no 'allow all'.

migration_steps: 1) Create SECURITY DEFINER function public.is_member_of(org_id, uid) owned by the table owner.
2) DROP the self-referencing and duplicate SELECT policies on organization_members.
3) (Re)create a single consolidated SELECT policy using is_member_of(...) + keep service-role policy.
4) DROP 'organizations_allow_all' and replace with a membership-based SELECT policy.
5) Verify with canary queries (see below).

canary_tests.name: Self user can select only their own memberships
canary_tests.sql: SET ROLE authenticated; SELECT count(*) FROM public.organization_members WHERE user_id = auth.uid();
canary_tests.expect: succeeds; returns only rows for current user

canary_tests.name: Member can see other members of same org (via join, not recursion)
canary_tests.sql: SELECT count(*) FROM public.organization_members m2 WHERE m2.organization_id IN (SELECT organization_id FROM public.organization_members WHERE user_id = auth.uid());
canary_tests.expect: succeeds; no recursion error

canary_tests.name: Non-member cannot see other org memberships
canary_tests.expect: returns zero rows

canary_tests.name: Organizations SELECT restricted
canary_tests.expect: returns only organizations where user is a member (unless service_role)

lint_rules.description: Detect policies that SELECT from the same table they protect.
lint_rules.pattern: USING contains subquery referencing current table name
lint_rules.suggestion: Move membership logic into a SECURITY DEFINER helper and call it in the policy.

lint_rules.description: Multiple SELECT policies with overlapping predicates on same table.
lint_rules.suggestion: Consolidate into a single SELECT policy with clear OR conditions.

lint_rules.description: Detect FOR ALL/SELECT USING(true) on sensitive tables that shadow restrictive policies.
lint_rules.suggestion: Remove allow-all or guard behind service_role only.

artifacts.notes: Ensure the helper function owner is a role exempt from RLS (table owner). In Supabase, functions run with their owner privileges when SECURITY DEFINER is set, avoiding recursion.

summary.embedding_text: Fix magic link authentication timing issue where immediate redirect causes session not to be established before middleware check. Use auth state change listener to wait for SIGNED_IN event before redirecting to dashboard. Critical: Supabase magic link auth is asynchronous - session establishment takes time.

context.framework: Next.js App Router with Supabase SSR
symptoms: Magic link clicked but user shows as 'Not authenticated' in middleware
Immediate redirect to dashboard fails with session not established
Works when manually accessing dashboard after magic link
Middleware logs show: 'User: Not authenticated' then later 'User: email@domain.com'
Browser console shows: 'Auth confirm params: { code: "...", tokenHash: null, type: null }'
context.observed_error: AuthApiError: invalid request: both auth code and code verifier should be non-empty

debugging_logs.middleware_logs:
üîê Middleware - Path: /auth/confirm
üë§ User: Not authenticated
üîê Middleware - Path: /dashboard
üë§ User: Not authenticated
üö´ Redirecting to login - no user on protected route: /dashboard
debugging_logs.browser_console: üîó Auth confirm params: { code: "55166e45-81f6-4d62-a98b-822565069d6f", tokenHash: null, type: null, errorParam: null, errorDescription: null }

context.root_cause: Magic link authentication in Supabase is asynchronous. When the magic link is clicked, the session is established server-side, but the client-side JavaScript needs to wait for the auth state change event to know when the session is ready. Immediate redirects happen before the session is established.

bad_patterns.name: Immediate redirect after magic link
bad_patterns.why_bad: Magic link authentication is asynchronous - session takes time to establish. This causes the middleware to see 'Not authenticated' and redirect to login.

bad_patterns.name: PKCE code exchange without verifier
bad_patterns.why_bad: PKCE flow requires code verifier parameter, but magic links don't provide one in the URL.

bad_patterns.name: Wrong session structure access
bad_patterns.why_bad: Supabase session object has nested structure: sessionData.session.user, not sessionData.user directly.

good_pattern.title: Auth state change listener with proper session handling
why_good: Waits for actual authentication event (SIGNED_IN)
Handles both new and existing sessions
Proper cleanup with unsubscribe to prevent memory leaks
No PKCE complications - uses auth state listener instead
Correct session structure: sessionData.session.user

migration_steps: 1) Replace immediate redirect with auth state listener
2) Add session check for already authenticated users
3) Use proper session structure (sessionData.session.user not sessionData.user)
4) Clean up listener subscription when done
5) Test magic link flow end-to-end
6) Add console logging to debug auth state changes
7) Verify middleware logs show authenticated user

canary_tests.test: Click magic link and check middleware logs
canary_tests.expect: User shows as authenticated in middleware: 'üë§ User: email@domain.com (uuid)'

canary_tests.name: Auth state listener fires
canary_tests.test: Check browser console for SIGNED_IN event
canary_tests.expect: Console shows 'üîê Auth state change: SIGNED_IN email@domain.com'

canary_tests.name: Redirect happens after session
canary_tests.test: Verify redirect to dashboard only after authentication
canary_tests.expect: No intermediate redirect to login page

canary_tests.name: Session structure is correct
canary_tests.test: Check that sessionData.session.user exists
canary_tests.expect: No 'user' property in session type errors

lint_rules.description: Avoid immediate redirects after auth actions that are asynchronous.
lint_rules.pattern: router.push() called immediately after auth method
lint_rules.suggestion: Use auth state change listener or add delay

lint_rules.description: Use correct session object structure in Supabase.
lint_rules.suggestion: Access user via sessionData.session.user

lint_rules.description: Always unsubscribe from auth state change listeners.
lint_rules.suggestion: Call subscription.unsubscribe() when done

lint_rules.description: Magic link authentication is asynchronous - wait for SIGNED_IN event.
lint_rules.pattern: Magic link redirect without auth state listener
lint_rules.suggestion: Use onAuthStateChange listener to wait for SIGNED_IN event

artifacts.notes: Magic link authentication in Supabase is asynchronous. The session is established server-side when the link is clicked, but the client needs to wait for the auth state change event to know when it's ready. The key insight is that middleware runs immediately but the session takes time to establish, causing the 'Not authenticated' ‚Üí redirect to login ‚Üí then later 'authenticated' pattern.

summary.embedding_text: Fix Google OAuth authentication error where user creation succeeds but database profile creation fails due to missing profiles table and RLS policies. Create profiles table with proper RLS policies and automatic profile creation trigger for new OAuth users.

context.framework: Next.js App Router with Supabase SSR
symptoms: Google OAuth redirects successfully but shows 'Authentication Error'
Error message: 'Database error saving new user'
OAuth flow works with some emails but fails with others
User appears in auth.users but no profile record created
context.observed_error: Authentication Error: There was an error with your authentication. Please try again. Database error saving new user

debugging_logs.database_failure: Error occurs during profile record creation
debugging_logs.missing_table: profiles table does not exist in database
debugging_logs.rls_blocking: No RLS policies allow profile creation for new users

context.root_cause: Supabase OAuth creates auth.users record but fails to create corresponding profile record due to missing profiles table and RLS policies that block profile creation for new users.

bad_patterns.name: Missing profiles table
bad_patterns.why_bad: OAuth users have no profile record, breaking app functionality that depends on profiles table.

bad_patterns.name: No RLS policies on profiles
bad_patterns.why_bad: RLS blocks all access to profiles table, preventing new user profile creation.

bad_patterns.name: Manual profile creation
bad_patterns.why_bad: Client-side profile creation is unreliable and can fail due to RLS policies or network issues.

good_pattern.title: Automatic profile creation with proper RLS policies
why_good: Automatic profile creation on user signup
Proper RLS policies allow users to manage their own profiles
SECURITY DEFINER function bypasses RLS for profile creation
Works for all OAuth providers (Google, GitHub, etc.)
No client-side profile creation needed

migration_steps: 1) Create profiles table with proper structure
2) Enable RLS and create policies for user profile management
3) Create SECURITY DEFINER function for automatic profile creation
4) Create trigger to fire on new user signup
5) Test OAuth flow with new users
6) Verify profile records are created automatically

canary_tests.expect: Profile record created automatically with user ID and name

canary_tests.test: Try to access other user's profile
canary_tests.expect: Only own profile accessible, others blocked

canary_tests.name: Profile updates work
canary_tests.test: Update own profile information
canary_tests.expect: Profile updates successfully

canary_tests.test: Delete user from auth.users
canary_tests.expect: Profile record deleted automatically due to CASCADE

lint_rules.description: OAuth apps should have profiles table for user data.
lint_rules.suggestion: Create profiles table with proper RLS policies

lint_rules.description: Tables with RLS enabled must have policies.
lint_rules.pattern: ALTER TABLE ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY without policies
lint_rules.suggestion: Create appropriate RLS policies for table access

lint_rules.description: Avoid manual client-side profile creation for OAuth.
lint_rules.suggestion: Use database triggers for automatic profile creation

lint_rules.description: OAuth apps should have user creation triggers.
lint_rules.suggestion: Create trigger to automatically create profiles for new users

artifacts.notes: OAuth authentication creates auth.users records but apps typically need additional user data in a profiles table. The trigger approach ensures profiles are created automatically without relying on client-side code, which can fail due to RLS policies or network issues.

summary.embedding_text: Implement welcome email system using Supabase Edge Functions with Resend integration. Handle CORS, authentication, and email delivery for new user signups. Create secure client-side approach to avoid database security issues.

context.framework: Next.js App Router with Supabase Edge Functions
context.version: Next.js 15, Supabase Edge Functions v2, Resend v2.0.0
symptoms: No welcome emails sent to new users
Supabase Auth only sends authentication emails
Custom email content needed for user onboarding
Database trigger approach has security vulnerabilities
context.observed_error: No specific error - enhancement request for custom email functionality

debugging_logs.cors_error: Access to fetch blocked by CORS policy
debugging_logs.email_logging: Email content logged but not sent

context.root_cause: Supabase Auth can only send authentication emails (magic links, OTP). Custom emails like welcome messages require Edge Functions with external email services like Resend, SendGrid, or AWS SES.

bad_patterns.name: Database trigger with service role key
bad_patterns.why_bad: Service role key in database is a major security vulnerability. Anyone with database access can read the key and bypass all RLS policies.

bad_patterns.name: Missing CORS headers
bad_patterns.why_bad: Browser blocks cross-origin requests without proper CORS headers, causing 404/network errors.

bad_patterns.name: Missing authentication
bad_patterns.why_bad: Edge Functions require authentication. Missing Authorization header causes 401 errors.

bad_patterns.name: Logging instead of sending
bad_patterns.why_bad: Users don't receive emails, only logs are generated. No actual email delivery.

good_pattern.title: Secure Edge Function with Resend integration
good_pattern.environment_setup:
// Set in Supabase Dashboard ‚Üí Edge Functions ‚Üí Environment Variables
RESEND_API_KEY=re_xxxxxxxxx
SUPABASE_SERVICE_ROLE_KEY=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...
SITE_URL=http://localhost:3000
why_good: Environment variables keep secrets secure
CORS headers enable cross-origin requests
Authentication ensures only authorized calls
Resend provides reliable email delivery
Professional email templates with HTML/text fallback
Error handling for failed email delivery

migration_steps: 1) Create Edge Function with Resend integration
2) Set up environment variables in Supabase
3) Add CORS headers to Edge Function
4) Implement client-side calls with authentication
5) Test email delivery with Resend
6) Verify CORS and authentication work
7) Add error handling for failed deliveries

lint_rules.suggestion: Add Access-Control-Allow-Origin headers to all responses

lint_rules.description: Edge Functions should require authentication.

lint_rules.description: Never store secrets in database tables.
lint_rules.suggestion: Use environment variables for sensitive data

artifacts.notes: Edge Functions provide the perfect solution for custom emails in Supabase. The client-side approach is more secure than database triggers, and Resend offers excellent deliverability for transactional emails. Environment variables keep secrets secure while CORS headers enable browser requests.
